# üá±üá∞ Sri Lanka This Week

![LastUpdated](https://img.shields.io/badge/last_updated-2025--12--26_06:18:48-green)
[![RSS](https://img.shields.io/badge/RSS-Feed-orange)](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nuuuwan/lk_news_digest/refs/heads/main/rss.xml)

*Generated by gpt-5 from 180 English News Articles published between 2025-12-19 and 2025-12-25.*

## 1. Cyclone Ditwah has morphed from a weather shock into an economic test Sri Lanka cannot afford to fail

With nearly two million people affected and direct physical damage preliminarily estimated at about $4.1 billion (World Bank GRADE), the cyclone is now a macroeconomic event. The ILO reckons up to 374,000 workers are affected and potential monthly earnings losses could reach $48 million, with rice, fisheries and tea hardest hit. The State has mobilised a Rs. 500 billion supplementary estimate and a ‚ÄòRebuilding Sri Lanka‚Äô fund; the BOI has set up a 24/7 support unit to unblock import/export and damaged-goods issues for investors. Success will hinge on more than cash: science-led land-use and early warning (NBRO), landslide mitigation rather than ad‚Äëhoc resettlement, and credible oversight of spend. The prize is stabilising 2025 growth and reducing the country‚Äôs structural exposure to climate shocks; the penalty is deeper output losses and a longer recovery. üåÄ

## 2. India‚Äôs fast deployment and a $450 m package reposition New Delhi as Colombo‚Äôs first responder

External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar‚Äôs visit underscored India‚Äôs role: Operation Sagar Bandhu flew in medicines and rations, an Indian Army field hospital treated patients, and 228 tons of Bailey bridges helped restore connectivity; India also pledged a $450 m recovery package (including a $100 m grant). The symbolism matters‚Äîespecially as Sri Lanka reassures tourists in peak season. Europe, Japan and Pakistan also extended assistance, while the EU activated its civil protection mechanism to airlift 83 tonnes of relief. In geopolitics, reliability trumps rhetoric; India‚Äôs mix of logistics, finance and political signalling met that standard. üáÆüá≥ü§ù

## 3. Domestic capital is showing up: corporate Sri Lanka is turning CSR into disaster capital expenditure

Private balance sheets are reinforcing public outlays. Cargills gave Rs. 100 m to the national fund and Rs. 45 m in rations; HNB committed Rs. 100 m and 2,500 relief packs; LOLC launched a three‚Äëphase Rs. 400 m programme, from family ‚Äòsuper packs‚Äô to rebuilding 200 schools; Sri Lanka Insurance supported 1,000 families; Lion Brewery cleared debris and boats in Biyagama; The Technocity earmarked Rs. 50 m in devices and school infrastructure; Pyramid Wilmar, Tristar UAE, Asriel Marketing and others wrote cheques. The lesson: public‚Äìprivate partnerships (PPPs) can scale relief quickly. The caveat: all flows‚Äîcorporate and State‚Äîmust be transparently tracked through the Rebuilding Fund to sustain trust. üí∏

## 4. Without an Auditor General, post‚Äëcyclone rupees will lack a referee

The Auditor General‚Äôs post has been vacant since 7 December. CoPF Chair Harsha de Silva warns the gap disables Parliament‚Äôs control over public finance (Articles 148 and 154), blinding COPA and COPE just as reconstruction accelerates. The Government has urged the Constitutional Council to either approve one of the four nominees or explain rejections; the Bar Association also flagged the vacancy. In disaster times, speed is vital‚Äîbut so are scorekeepers. Filling the post is the single cheapest way to improve the probity of every rupee spent. ‚öñÔ∏è

## 5. Sri Lanka must treat landslides as a management problem‚Äînot just a humanitarian one

Columns this week highlighted the engineering logic: saturated soils over weak bedrock, adverse bedding planes, and unmanaged drainage make Central Highlands slopes fail. Experts proposed a National Landslide Risk Management Authority, scaled bio‚Äëengineering and sub‚Äësurface drainage, and moving from blanket ‚Äòred zones‚Äô to targeted mitigation at upper catchments. Equally, knee‚Äëjerk bans on construction above altitude lines or relocating entire districts would be disruptive and unscientific; better to follow the evidence‚Äëbased National Physical Plan 2050, invest in early warning (in all national languages), and build dry dams and flood bunds where rivers have no reservoirs. üèîÔ∏è

## 6. Markets and money are edging back, even as risk premia nudge up

The CSE has been volatile‚ÄîDockyard‚Äôs rights issue overhang hit prices before rebounding on India aid headlines; institutional crossings in blue‚Äëchips kept turnover healthy. Unit trust AUM rose 16.5% YoY to Rs. 597 bn by November, with equity funds seeing fresh inflows and 141,252 investors now in the market. Treasury bill yields ticked up at auction as the Central Bank accepted fewer bids, and the rupee was broadly steady around Rs. 309.5/US$. On the real economy‚Äôs digital rails, Dialog commercially launched 5G with 220 live sites, SLT‚ÄëMOBITEL opened public 5G access, and NSB rolled out Tap‚Äëand‚ÄëGo via Mastercard‚Äîsmall tailwinds for productivity as reconstruction ramps. üìàüì°

## 7. Policy tweaks signal pragmatism: bait‚Äëfish tariffs, stalled hospitals and urban tenders are back on the table

Cabinet created a dedicated HS code to import milk fish for long‚Äëline tuna bait‚Äîrestricted to fishing societies‚Äîand replaced Wekkaya tariffs with a special trade tax of Rs. 180/kg, with Rs. 130/kg concessions for societies. It also restarted eight hospital projects (A&E units, cardiology and clinic buildings, surgical wards), now estimated at Rs. 16.2 bn vs. Rs. 6.7 bn earlier‚Äîan expensive reminder of the cost of delay. The UDA will re‚Äëinvite proposals for a prime Fort plot on a 99‚Äëyear lease after an empty 2024 tender, and named former JICA specialist M.G. Hemachandra as Chairman‚Äîuseful signals to investors that the real‚Äëasset pipeline is moving again. üß±

## 8. Hard cases should not make bad laws: security and media rules need restraint, not mission creep

Two red flags appeared. A civil‚Äësociety collective warned that the draft Protection of the State from Terrorism Act (PSTA) largely reproduces PTA‚Äëstyle defects‚Äîadministrative detention up to two years and overbroad speech offences‚Äîrisking protest and journalism through vague definitions. Separately, the Editors‚Äô Guild criticised the CID‚Äôs summons to a newspaper editor and a Deputy Minister‚Äôs remarks inviting police action against ‚Äòdefamation‚Äô of the President under emergency rules. Post‚Äëdisaster legitimacy relies on open scrutiny, not muscular opacity; keeping emergency powers narrow and the press free is a resilience measure, too. üì∞

## Model Prompt (for [gpt-5](https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-5))

```
You will be given several Sri Lankan news articles from the past week. Write a concise, cohesive editorial digest in the style of The Economist, but output it as a JSON list. Each list element must be a dict of the form:

{
  "title": "...",
  "body": "..."
}

Titles should be written as crisp, fully informative sentences. Follow each title with a short paragraph in "body" that adds context and nuance without bullets.

Go beyond summary and analyse how the week‚Äôs developments fit together. Use emojis purposefully, and explain any non-obvious acronyms or jargon. Stick strictly to verifiable facts.
```
